Comment: So, my opponent opens with d3.
My response is e5, which I often use. !Very! often :D
Bareq plays Na3, which seemed me a bit strange, because if I had taken his knight with my bishop, he would have doubled pawns on the edge of the board.
But I didn't take it, I played Nf6 instead. I chose this option because I don't like closed games, so bishops can be useful later.
e3 followed. It didn't seem that my opponent wanted to use his bishops.
But I wanted, so I opened the way of my LSB, and also set a pawn into the centre.
Bareq plays Nf3, atacking my e5 pawn.
I didn't allow to capture it, I pinned it to his  queen.
But now if I don't want to lose a pawn, I have to take his knight.
Ok, done.
My opponent plays Qxf3, taking my bishop.

Then I played c6, and my future plant was to bring my knight from b8 to d7. And look at the white piece on a3. It cannot go to the centre. I think my opponent's next move was to move it closer to the center, so
he played c3 attacking d4, and also freeing some place for his knight (the c2 square) to go, and later to approach the centre.
A simple developing move defending my e5 pawn and preparing a short castling.
Why does he want to take his king with his knight???:D
My king is on a safe square, and I think I am OK with developing.
Hm... Seems my opponent wants to attack my kingside...
Never mind :D
Whoah! He comes closer and closer.
Again, never mind :D
